bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Hon.W.H.Seward Washington
Sir
Your communication of July 3rd, and Circular of August 28th with the form of the Oath of Allegiance have been received. The duties of the Agency in Gaboon have not been onerous. In consequence of the Presidents Proclamation of July, I think, relating to Citizens of the United States returning to the States, I gave a certificate of citizenship to Miss Jane A. VanAllen, who sailed from this port Nov. 1st in its Big Ocean Eagle', Phillip P. Yates Minister, bound to New York. As is a free port, + neither any duties as a Missionary permitting on the interest of humanity requiring, I did not perform any official duties toward the . I also am in doubt whether your better of July 3rd authroizing any such official acts.
But it is now my painful duty to inform you of the death of Capt. R.E.Lawlin of New York. Agent for James Bishop Heo. of No,G. Beaver I heed New York. Captain Lawlin was a trader of thirty years standing on this Coast. He died at Camma, about 150. Unites South of the Gaboon. His principla business was at that place. He had no responsible person about him. I have send the herd man I could find, to go + take charge of the property until I can find the means of bringing it to this place. I have written to the U.S. Sloop Saiatoga, + the French Commodere, Baron has offered any assistance in his power. But I shall not be able to give you particular information before the departure of this month's mail. I have not means of estimating the amount of property ledt in Comma*. It is in the midst of a barbarous people.
2
21st. I have just returned from paying a visit to the Commiodere. He told me at once that he had read a communication the enclosed which I lead the rumor to address to him on the 18th , at his request for a written statement of the Case of Capt. Lawlin. The purposed at once to send a steamer to the property in case the natives made any resistance to its removal. End
In regard to the Oath of Allegiance he said there was no one here authorized to administer the oath, but he would direct the Commanddant on shere to writing may signature to it this I will attend to at any earliest convience, [The Commicdere* apured me that the simple request as an American citizen, for assistance to secure the property of an American citizen was all he required. I have engaged an English Barque to go + bring the goods to this place. I have written very full to refers Janes Bishop H.O, + have requested
3
them to despatch an Agent immediately to take charge of this business I shall try + keep within the law in my business transactions + must beg your indulgence for any information in my communications.
I would simply add that after considerable inquiry, I suppose the amount of African produce + goods in the factory at Camma must be between $10,000 + $15,000 ten thousand + fifteen thousand dollars. They associate in Missionary labor, Rev. J. M. Preston, will go to Comma in the vessel to attend to the shippinh of the goods + settling up Capt. Lawlins business there. The is a perfectly reliable . It seems to be impossible for me to go.
I am Sir, Your obedient Servant W.Walker
